Introduction

Hyperprolactinemia is a condition characterized by elevated serum prolactin levels.  It can result from physiologic processes, medications, or pathologic conditions (eg, prolactinomas).  High prolactin levels suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, causing hypogonadism and galactorrhea.  Patients with hyperprolactinemia may also present with symptoms related to mass effect from tumors.

Regulation of prolactin secretion



Prolactin is secreted by lactotroph cells in the anterior pituitary gland.  It is under constant negative regulation by dopaminergic neurons via the pituitary stalk (

figure 1
); dopamine released by these neurons binds to lactotroph D2 receptors and suppresses prolactin production (normal: <20 ng/mL in men and postmenopausal women; <30 ng/mL in premenopausal women).



The negative regulation of prolactin contrasts with the regulation of most other pituitary hormones (eg, LH, TSH), which are under positive regulation on stimulation by releasing hormones (eg, GnRH, thyrotropin-releasing hormone [TRH]) from the hypothalamus.

Causes of hyperprolactinemia



Hyperprolactinemia can occur as part of normal physiologic changes in women (eg, pregnancy).  Pathologic causes of hyperprolactinemia in men and women include the effects of medications inhibiting dopamine secretion, tumors (eg, prolactinomas), or systemic disorders.

Physiologic changes



Physiologic processes that increase prolactin secretion in women include:



  • Pregnancy:  Increased estrogen levels in pregnancy cause lactotroph hyperplasia, resulting in hyperprolactinemia; basal prolactin levels return to normal 6 weeks postpartum.
  • Breastfeeding:  In lactating women, nipple stimulation activates neural pathways, leading to transient hyperprolactinemia; it is most pronounced in the early postpartum phase.  In nonlactating women, nipple stimulation from procedures (eg, mammography) or breast examinations does not produce an elevation in prolactin secretion.


In addition, transient increases in prolactin are sometimes seen following meal consumption, exercise, and intense stress.

Medications



Drugs that block D2 receptors (ie, dopamine receptor antagonists) interfere with dopaminergic suppression of prolactin, resulting in hyperprolactinemia.  With few exceptions, medication-induced hyperprolactinemia typically causes only a moderate elevation (<100 ng/mL).  Levels of serum prolactin return to baseline following discontinuation of the drug.



The most common examples of medications implicated in hyperprolactinemia include:



  • Antipsychotics:  First-generation antipsychotics (eg, haloperidol); markedly elevated prolactin can occur with risperidone (eg, >200 ng/mL).  Second-generation (atypical) antipsychotics (eg, aripiprazole) are usually associated with much milder elevations because they have a lower affinity for the D2 receptor.
  • Other agents:  Gastric motility drugs, including metoclopramide.

Pathologic causes



Pathologic causes of hyperprolactinemia can affect men and women; they include prolactin-secreting tumors or neurologic disorders that block dopamine secretion and transport.  In addition, certain systemic diseases are associated with hyperprolactinemia.



  • Prolactin-secreting tumors (prolactinoma):  Prolactinomas are the most common pathologic cause of hyperprolactinemia in premenopausal women; they occur due to the monoclonal proliferation of lactotroph cells.  Rarely, they can be malignant (eg, in association with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes).
  • Pituitary or hypothalamic disorders:  Other hypothalamic or pituitary tumors (functioning or nonfunctioning), infiltrative diseases (eg, neurosarcoidosis obstructing the hypophyseal portal system), and head trauma interfere with dopamine secretion or transport and result in hyperprolactinemia.
  • Primary hypothyroidism:  TRH production in the hypothalamus is increased due to insufficient thyroxine production; TRH appears to have a stimulatory effect on lactotroph cells (
    figure 2
    ), leading to hyperprolactinemia.
  • Other conditions:  Chronic kidney disease is associated both with decreased prolactin clearance and increased secretion.  In addition, conditions affecting the chest wall (eg, burns, herpes zoster) may lead to increased prolactin due to effects similar to those of nipple stimulation.

Clinical presentation



Prolactin-secreting microadenomas may be asymptomatic and incidentally discovered on MRI.  When symptomatic, the earliest manifestations of hyperprolactinemia commonly involve hypogonadism.  This occurs because elevated prolactin levels suppress hypothalamic GnRH production, leading to central hypogonadism characterized by:



  • Low GnRH, LH, and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • Low estrogen (
    image 1
    ), progesterone, and/or testosterone (
    image 2
    ).

Symptoms



The following populations experience common symptoms of hyperprolactinemia:



  • Premenopausal women:  Overt symptoms include menstrual changes (oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea), galactorrhea (bilateral white nipple discharge), vasomotor symptoms (eg, hot flashes), vaginal dryness and atrophy, sexual dysfunction (eg, dyspareunia), and anovulatory infertility.  Mild hyperprolactinemia (eg, <50 ng/dL) is usually associated with milder symptoms (eg, oligomenorrhea), whereas moderate to severe hyperprolactinemia (eg, >100 ng/dL) can manifest with more pronounced findings (eg, amenorrhea, vasomotor symptoms).
  • Men:  Nonspecific symptoms include infertility; decreased libido, muscle mass, and body hair; testicular atrophy; and impotence.  Gynecomastia is present in only about one-third of patients and is generally mild, and galactorrhea is uncommon because sufficient estrogen (primarily derived from androgens) is not present for this process to occur.
  • Postmenopausal women:  Hyperprolactinemia is often very difficult to diagnose in the early stages because hypogonadism is already present physiologically and galactorrhea is uncommon (due to insufficient estrogen reserves).  Long-standing hyperprolactinemia and resultant estrogen deficiency can impair bone health, leading to osteoporosis and fragility fractures (fractures due to minimal trauma such as a fall from a standing height).

Mass effects



Hyperprolactinemia can also present with mass-effect symptoms in the context of a large prolactinoma (eg, >1 cm, macroadenoma) or another nonfunctioning pituitary tumor.  This is often seen in men and postmenopausal women with prolactinoma who are diagnosed at later stages due to nonspecific early findings.



Mass-effect symptoms include:



  • Hypopituitarism.
  • Headache, nausea, vomiting.
  • Visual changes (eg, bitemporal hemianopia (
    figure 3
    )) due to pressure on surrounding structures such as the optic chiasm (
    figure 4
    ).

Diagnosis



Hyperprolactinemia should be considered as a potential cause in patients with unexplained galactorrhea or symptoms of hypogonadism, including infertility, menstrual dysfunction, and/or erectile dysfunction.



Prolactin levels should be measured in the following patients:



  • Women:  Symptoms of menstrual dysfunction, infertility, or unexplained galactorrhea.
  • Men:  Central hypogonadism confirmed by low testosterone and inappropriately normal or low FSH and LH (
    figure 5
    ).


Because prolactin levels vary with sleep, certain meals, and stress, testing should be repeated if an initial prolactin level is borderline elevated.  Very high prolactin levels (eg, â‰¥200 ng/mL) are typically seen with prolactinoma, whereas mild to moderate elevations can occur due to medications, hypothyroidism, or renal insufficiency.



In patients with confirmed hyperprolactinemia, the work-up centers on identifying the underlying cause, including:



  • Laboratory testing:  Ruling out physiologic processes if applicable (eg, pregnancy test), assessing renal and thyroid function (eg, glomerular filtration rate, TSH).
  • Medication review and physical examination:  Reviewing psychotropic medications, examining breast tissue, assessing for neurologic signs of tumor (eg, visual fields examination) or associated conditions (eg, hypothyroidism).


In addition, pituitary MRI should be ordered in patients with any of the following:



  • Elevated prolactin level:  All unexplained prolactin elevations warrant an MRI; in patients taking dopamine antagonists, pituitary MRI should be considered for levels >100 ng/dL (which are unexpected with most medications unless risperidone is being used).
  • Mass-effect symptoms.
  • Evidence of abnormalities in other pituitary hormone levels (eg, as with somatotroph or corticotroph adenomas).

Management



Management of hyperprolactinemia should address the underlying cause (eg, replacing culprit medications, if feasible; treating underlying hypothyroidism).



In patients with prolactinoma as a cause of hyperprolactinemia, treatment is indicated if any of the following symptoms are present:



  • Neurologic symptoms secondary to the size of the mass.
  • All hypogonadal symptoms.
  • Other manifestations of hyperprolactinemia (eg, galactorrhea).


In contrast, asymptomatic patients with an incidental finding of microprolactinoma may be observed over time, and medications are unnecessary (unless the patient is trying to conceive).



Management consists of treatment and monitoring, as follows:



  • Dopamine agonists:  Cabergoline is usually first-line therapy regardless of the adenoma size and the severity of neurologic symptoms; it typically reduces prolactin secretion and mass size.
  • Symptom monitoring:  Hypogonadal and mass-effect symptoms (eg, visual field defects) normally improve within the first several days to weeks of treatment, with eventual normalization in many cases.
  • Prolactin level monitoring:  Prolactin levels are expected to fall significantly within the first 2-3 weeks of therapy, but decreased tumor size may not be visible on imaging for several weeks.


Transsphenoidal surgery is considered for patients whose condition does not respond adequately to dopamine agonists and may be followed by radiation.  Otherwise, surgery is not needed; it is reserved for patients whose treatment fails or those who have very large tumors (>3 cm).  Even if surgery is performed, complete resection is often impossible, and recurrence is common, requiring medication therapy.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for hyperprolactinemia includes conditions that manifest with infertility, hypogonadism, and anovulation.  In women, these causes are usually distinguished based on associated symptoms and history and, if needed, measurement of FSH and LH levels.

Infertility



Acquired conditions associated with infertility (summarized in this table (

)) in men and/or women include:



  • Polycystic ovary syndrome:  Polycystic ovary syndrome is also associated with anovulation, menstrual irregularities, and, possibly, mild elevations in prolactin levels; however, it is characterized by increased androgen levels and FSH levels (not seen in hyperprolactinemia due to suppressed GnRH), and symptoms of acne and hirsutism.
  • Primary ovarian insufficiency:  Primary ovarian insufficiency involves loss of ovarian granulosa cells (eg, due to autoimmune disorder), resulting in low estrogen, infertility, and secondary amenorrhea; however, LH and FSH levels are elevated.
  • Primary testicular disorder:  Primary testicular disorder can also lead to symptoms of primary hypogonadism with low testosterone, in case of testicular damage (eg, torsion, radiation); unlike hyperprolactinemia, GnRH is elevated, leading to high FSH and LH levels.
  • Hypothalamic hypogonadism due to other causes:  Intense exercise, stress, or trauma can independently suppress GnRH (functional hypogonadism) production in both women and men.  In such cases, prolactin levels can be normal or minimally elevated.  The cause is usually apparent from the history, and work-up fails to identify a culprit medication or pathologic cause (ie, diagnosis of exclusion).

Gynecomastia



In men, gynecomastia can also be due to other tumors, (eg, testicular cancer), thyrotoxicosis, and medications (eg, cimetidine, spironolactone) (

table 3
).  However, in these disorders, gynecomastia occurs because of increased estrogen production or conversion (eg, androgen excess), whereas hyperprolactinemia is characterized by an androgen-deficient state.

Mass-effect symptoms



In both men and women, the differential diagnosis for mass-effect symptoms caused by prolactinomas includes other types of microadenomas and macroadenomas.  Any pituitary tumor of significant size that disrupts dopaminergic pathways can cause moderate hyperprolactinemia.  However, other pituitary tumors usually have pathognomonic associated manifestations (eg, somatotroph adenomas with acromegaly).

Complications



The main complications of hyperprolactinemia include:



  • Osteoporosis:  Estrogen maintains bone mass in premenopausal women.  Low estrogen levels lead to the increased production of inflammatory cytokines, resulting in increased osteoclast activity.  Loss of estrogen increases the risk for bone loss and osteoporosis.
  • Neurologic complications:  Visual impairment can result from optic chiasm compression, and pituitary apoplexy (sudden headache, vision loss, hypopituitarism) can occur with macroadenomas.

Considerations in pregnancy



The major risk for pregnancy with prolactinoma involves potential tumor enlargement and associated neurologic compromise (eg, visual deficits) with rising estrogen levels.  This risk is associated primarily with a preexisting macroadenoma (>1 cm) rather than a microadenoma.



The following guidelines are recommended for women with preexisting prolactinoma who intend to become pregnant:



  • Preconception:  Dopamine agonist treatment should be initiated to restore normal ovulation (and shrink tumor size, if >1 cm); fertility is often restored following normalization of prolactin levels.  In women with larger macroadenomas nonresponsive to medical therapy, transsphenoidal surgery can be considered to minimize the risk for pathologic enlargement during pregnancy.
  • During pregnancy:  Regular examinations (eg, every 3 months) are recommended with an assessment of visual fields and screening for concerning symptoms (eg, headaches).  Measurement of serum prolactin levels and MRIs are not routinely indicated.  Dopamine agonist therapy should be restarted if concerning symptoms occur or in the case of suspected adenoma enlargement.
  • Postpartum:  Dopamine agonists are not recommended because breastfeeding does not appear to significantly increase adenoma size.  Prolactin levels should be monitored following cessation of breastfeeding.

Prognosis



Most microprolactinomas (~90%) respond well to dopamine agonists, with eventual normalization of prolactin levels and resolution of symptoms.  Macroadenomas often shrink significantly with medical therapy but may require long-term surveillance and monitoring.  Surgical and radiotherapy outcomes vary, with a risk of recurrence necessitating continued follow-up.

Summary



Hyperprolactinemia results from excess prolactin production due to a range of physiologic, pharmacologic, or pathologic causes, with prolactinomas being the most common etiology.  The condition primarily disrupts reproductive function and, in macroadenomas, can cause mass-effect symptoms.  Diagnosis relies on serum prolactin measurement and pituitary MRI.  Management typically involves dopamine agonists, with surgery or radiotherapy reserved for resistant cases.  Left untreated, hyperprolactinemia may lead to infertility, osteoporosis, and visual deficits, but the overall prognosis is favorable with appropriate intervention.
